instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00875: What is 820-00875? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP3V3_S0SW_LCD: What is PP3V3_S0SW_LCD? PP3V3_S0SW_LCD is a 3.3v power rail necessary to power the image circuitry on the screen. This is necessary to get a picture on the screen. .
definitions.EDP_PANEL_PWR_EN: What is EDP_PANEL_PWR_EN? EDP_PANEL_PWR_EN is necessary to enable the power rail that powers the LCD screen image circuitry. Signals with _EN on the end enable whatever came before the _EN if the signal is high. .
definitions.SMC_LID_LEFT: What is SMC_LID_LEFT? SMC_LID_LEFT is a signal that tells the system if the lid is closed from the left LID sensor. If it is low, the system thinks the lid is closed – if it is 3.3v, the system thinks the machine is open. SMC_LID_LEFT needs to be high for the machine to stay awake and have a backlight. .
definitions.SMC_LID_RIGHT: What is SMC_LID_RIGHT? SMC_LID_RIGHT is a signal that tells the system if the lid is closed from the right LID sensor. If it is low, the system thinks the lid is closed – if it is 3.3v, the system thinks the machine is open. SMC_LID_RIGHT needs to be high for the machine to stay awake and have a backlight. .
definitions.HALL_SENSOR_RIGHT: What is HALL_SENSOR_RIGHT? HALL_SENSOR_RIGHT is a signal from the hall sensor on the RIGHT side of the machine that indicates that the lid has been closed. This is necessary for setting SMC_LID properly so the machine knows whether it is closed or open. When this is low, the machine will think it is closed which may cause it to go to sleep or have no backlight on the screen.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Internal screen not working
threads.message:
I have this one with no image or backlight on internal screen. External screen works fine.

History is customer tried to replace cracked screen (which had image and backlight but with broken LCD). He somehow replaced the screen with the power applied and now no screens are working. Also not the original broken one. Tried two new known-good ones. The original with crack also works i another machine. So logic board issue here.

If something shorted because of connecting the screen while powered on what would be the first suspects ? I cannot see or smell anything burned...

<SIGNAL>PP5V_S0SW_LCD</SIGNAL> = 0V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0SW_LCD</SIGNAL> = 0V
<SIGNAL>EDP_PANEL_PWR_EN</SIGNAL> = 0V
<SIGNAL>PANEL_P5V_EN</SIGNAL> = 0V
<SIGNAL>PANEL_P3V3_EN</SIGNAL> = 0V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Internal screen not working
threads.message:
Damaged connector would be a first suspect. Next would be a diode mode test on all pins. Both screens have a LCD cable, you did not swap that over so that could be the problem?

Also inspect for damaged/knocked off components around LCD connector, easy to do with tool or nails.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Internal screen not working
threads.message:
Connector on logic board looking perfect as well as connector on LCD board also have no visible damage. I tried already with several LCD cables. Also all components around this area are in place and with none visible damage. 

I will take the diode measurements on the LCD connector but I can only do it with the LCD (cable) disconnected as the connector is put in from the top in this model. Would this be fine ?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Internal screen not working
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Internal screen not working
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Internal screen not working
threads.message: That looks ok. Make sure to check all caps <CAPACITOR>C8520</CAPACITOR>-29 for damage. If that is ok then the sucky part of checking power to the LCD on pin 44 and 45. Check while powering on as there may only be power there for a second if no screen is recognized.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Internal screen not working
threads.message:
The caps are looking splendid and measuring between 80-100 nF in circuit.

I get a spike once while powering on at pin 44 and 45:

Pin 44: 3.30V for 600ms
Pin 45: 5.12V for 600ms

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Internal screen not working
threads.message:
That is what happens if no LCD is connected. I'm still suspecting the connector, pins 1,3,4,6 are important for LCD detection. See if they have continuity to the other side of the LCD cable.

Power pins too of course 44 and 45.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Internal screen not working
threads.message: Pins 1,3,4,6,44,45 have continuity to the other side of the LCD cable. I measured from nearby probe points as the LCD cable connected is making it impossible to measure on the connector directly

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Internal screen not working
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Internal screen not working
threads.message: Pins 44,45 were measured with LCD connected if there was a pulse?  Need to make sure they also have that voltage when a load is connected. This one is getting annoying. There is of course the possibility that both LCD were fucked up somehow.....

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Internal screen not working
threads.message:
Yup tell me about it...

Pins 44,45 have spike with both the screen connected and disconnected.

Both LCD are working for sure because I have another <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> that they work on. I have tested with three displays (two good ones and a cracked one). All three working on good board. None working on bad board...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Internal screen not working
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Internal screen not working
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>SMC_LID_LEFT</SIGNAL> = 3.37 V
<SIGNAL>SMC_LID_LEFT_R</SIGNAL> = 3.37 V

<SIGNAL>SMC_LID_RIGHT</SIGNAL> = 3.37 V (only with audio flex cable connected in J6600, otherwise ~10mV)
<SIGNAL>HALL_SENSOR_RIGHT</SIGNAL> = 3.40 V (only with audio flex cable connected in J6600, otherwise ~10mV)

<SIGNAL>LID_OPEN</SIGNAL> = 3.37 V
<SIGNAL>LID_OPEN_R</SIGNAL> = 3.40 V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Internal screen not working
threads.message: Kind of out of ideas right now. Experience with these is still limited of course. Got a working board to compare things with? See what happens on <SIGNAL>BUF_EDP_PANEL_PWR_EN</SIGNAL> too.
